messageBody:
Benct Philip Jonsson wrote:

On 2008-11-04 Benct Philip Jonsson wrote:


Above all I don't think
non-native writers want to be told to spell as they
guess or imagine that a word should be pronounced in
the accent of English which they aim to speak. That
would be te reintroduce the some trouble we have with
TO by the back door.









A non-native speaker learning English will use books designed for that purpose.  Once the content is digital, it will probably become quite simple for the spelling in that primer to be altered automatically to match the accent that the student wants to learn.  And once there are newspapers, magazines etc. available in QS, as the student reads them, the spelling in them will begin to make sense to the student and will indicate the pronunciation to him.  He will not be in the situation of "guessing" how a word should be pronounced.  He will be led down a structured path toward relative English fluency.

This is quite different from telling people who are already fluent English speakers that they must memorize how words should be spelt in QS.  An alphabet is simply a code for getting the sounds of a language down on paper or an electronic screen to transmit information to others.  If the code is not closely related to the way people actually speak, then we are setting ourselves up for failure in my estimation.

Paige
